data.title: Memoir essays that led to a book deal
data.meta_description: Writing a memoir essay is a quick way to jump the queue to a book deal for your memoir. Read on for examples of essays that led to memoir book deals!
data.text:
Did you know that getting an essay published is a quick way to not just build your platform, but could also help you skip the queue to getting a book deal?

This post is going to teach you why a memoir essay can lead to a book deal, and give you actual recent examples of memoir writers who landed their book deal from a published essay. Each essay and book is linked in the title if you‚Äôd like to learn more!

Why a memoir essay can lead to a book deal

I‚Äôll tell you why. Writing an essay around the topic or theme of your memoir is a great idea for getting exposure, getting paid (!) and many more reasons, and it can also help you land an agent, publisher or editor for your book.

It did for me, and it has done for each of the writers listed below.

In a nutshell: Published essays can and do lead to book deals because‚Ä¶

Having a top editor or publisher see your story gain traction online can fast-track your submission (or even mean you don‚Äôt need to make one!)

One caveat: it‚Äôs still going to take work. You‚Äôll need to develop your proposal and/or the manuscript. But having a piece online is like having your synopsis out to ‚Äòshop‚Äô before you‚Äôve even submitted a book proposal. It will also (and this, to me, is the more valuable outcome) give you the most important insights into which parts of your story resonate with readers which you can then use as you shape your book proposal or the finished manuscript.

The great thing about getting a book deal from an essay, though, is that you‚Äôve proven you already have an audience.

Those hundreds of comments on your essay or emails from readers means your story resonates. This is why editors seek out books from viral stories: they‚Äôre online proof that the market is there for your book.

Read on for the wonderful times a memoir essay has led to a book deal and click on the links if you‚Äôd like to study the essays for tips. They‚Äôre all amazing examples of condensing a book-length memoir into a shorter narrative arc.

Stephanie Land‚Äôs essay in Vox led to her book deal for MAID

The essay was published in July 2015 and went viral, with almost 500 000 hits in two days. Land wrote in her online blog that she‚Äôd been developing the essay for two years.

When MAID came out less than four years later, it hit the New York Times bestseller list within weeks.

Moral of the deal: publishers see what the public likes ‚Äì if something goes viral, there‚Äôs a good chance it will sell well as a published book, too! Also ‚Äì the apple may take ages to ripen, but falls fast from the tree!

Kristi Coulter‚Äôs memoir Nothing Good Can Come of This was sold after this Medium essay went viral

Moral of this deal: you don‚Äôt have to be published in the New York Times. Medium is a great place to get published because people vote for your story in terms of popularity with ‚Äòclaps‚Äô. If it resonates on Medium, you can be sure it will resonate with the wider public.

Sasha Brown-Worsham‚Äôs memoir, Namaste The Hard Way, was sold after an acquisitions editor saw this essay in The New York Times and contacted her out of the blue

Ironically enough, Brown-Worsham says the essay was originally a pitch she‚Äôd written an agent to sell the story.

‚ÄúThe agent told me she didn‚Äôt see a memoir but that the pitch was lovely and I should sell it as an essay‚Ä¶.then the essay sold a memoir. Lightning strike luck!‚Äù

Moral of this deal: An essay is a good way to hone your pitch! Also ‚Äì don‚Äôt take one ‚Äòno‚Äô as the final üôÇ

Christine Hyung-Oak Lee is another example of an essay going viral leading to a deal. After this piece about her stroke at age 33 went live in Buzzfeed in 2014, she was contacted by two editors at big houses and eight agents. She ended up signing a two-book deal with Harper Collins. Tell Me Everything You Don‚Äôt Remember, her memoir, was based on the Buzzfeed essay. Her novel (the second book in the deal) is forthcoming.

Moral(s) of the deal: Buzzfeed gets a LOT of clicks & publishers LOVE platform. The essay is long (a clear sign you‚Äôre up to a longform work such as a novel), her writing is superb, and the story has multiple hooks (she didn‚Äôt realise she was having a stroke, is just one). Strong hooks doth a strong pitch make!

Kelly Sundberg‚Äôs exquisite essay for Guernica led to her book deal for Goodbye Sweet Girl

Theo Nestor‚Äôs How To Sleep Alone in a King-Sized bed was born from this essay in Modern Love.

Audrey Shulman‚Äôs Sitting in Bars With Cake deal came from the blog she started when she decided to take 50 cakes to bars in LA over the course of a year in the hopes of snagging a boyfriend.

Moral of this deal: you can even get a book deal from a blog. They key is traction, and visibility. Read this piece where she describes how it all unfolded.

Lastly, Cheryl Strayed wrote this breathtaking essay for the Sun magazine that eventually became WILD

Moral of the deal: write the most beautiful work around the pain of your story that you possibly can. People will see it.

In summary:

Honing your story via a shorter published essay can only strengthen your book proposal and helps you finesse which parts of your personal story are going to resonate with the WIDEST amount of people across the world. This is exactly why I teach this strategy in my programs. It‚Äôs a way to skip the queue of cold querying agents and editors!
